Literature Review: The field of metabolic engineering has seen significant advancements in recent years, driven by the increasing demand for sustainable production of chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and biofuels. One of the primary challenges in this field is optimizing the efficiency and yield of heterologous pathways introduced into host organisms. Low pathway flux and off-target consumption of intermediates are common issues that can severely limit the productivity of engineered systems. To address these challenges, researchers have turned to nature for inspiration, focusing on the spatial organization of enzymes within cells. This review explores the theoretical and practical aspects of multienzyme organization and encapsulation, highlighting key strategies such as protein scaffolding and bacterial microcompartments. Nature has evolved sophisticated mechanisms to enhance the efficiency of metabolic pathways through spatial organization. In eukaryotic cells, organelles like mitochondria and chloroplasts compartmentalize specific metabolic processes, reducing diffusion distances and increasing local substrate concentrations. Similarly, prokaryotes have developed protein-based structures known as bacterial microcompartments (BMCs) to sequester enzymes and their substrates, thereby enhancing pathway flux and reducing the impact of toxic intermediates. Protein scaffolding is another strategy inspired by natural systems. Scaffolds are designed to physically bring together multiple enzymes involved in a metabolic pathway, thereby facilitating efficient substrate channeling and reducing the likelihood of off-target reactions. This approach has been successfully applied in various contexts. The design of effective protein scaffolds requires a deep understanding of enzyme kinetics and interactions. Computational tools and high-throughput screening methods have played a crucial role in optimizing scaffold architectures. Bacterial microcompartments (BMCs) represent a more advanced form of spatial organization, offering additional benefits such as protection against toxic intermediates and enhanced stability of the encapsulated enzymes. One of the most well-studied examples of BMCs is the carboxysome, a BMC found in cyanobacteria and some chemoautotrophic bacteria. Carboxysomes encapsulate the CO2-fixing enzyme ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (RuBisCO) and carbonic anhydrase, which work together to enhance the efficiency of carbon fixation. Synthetic BMCs have been engineered to encapsulate enzymes involved in various metabolic processes, including the production of biofuels and pharmaceuticals. Despite the promising results, the application of protein scaffolding and BMCs in metabolic engineering faces several challenges. Another challenge is the scalability of these technologies. In conclusion, the spatial organization of enzymes through protein scaffolding and bacterial microcompartments offers a powerful approach to overcome the bottlenecks in metabolic engineering. Continued advances in computational design, high-throughput screening, and bioreactor technology will be crucial for realizing the full potential of these strategies in industrial applications.
